headline: Anti-‘Cancel Culture’ Rumble Offers Joe Rogan $100 Million To Leave Spotify
author: Marisa Dellatto
sentences:
Key Facts
In a letter signed by CEO Chris Pavlovski, Rumble offered Rogan “100 million bucks over four years” for his total library of shows—the same amount of money Rogan was reportedly paid by Spotify in 2020 when it became the exclusive publisher of his podcast—and promised “no censorship.”
Over 70 episodes of The Joe Rogan Experience were removed from Spotify Sunday after widespread criticism of Rogan’s use of racial slurs on the show—though in a letter apologizing to employees, Ek said the episodes were removed at Rogan’s request and Rogan’s show would remain on Spotify because “silencing” and “canceling voices” is “not the answer.”
Still, there’s plenty of skepticism that partisan vehicles like Rumble resemble the short-lived success of meme stocks, and support them, as Forbes wrote in December, seems “more about investing in a social statement than a wager on future cash flows or profits.”
Animosity against Rogan and his show started building last month over misinformation about Covid-19 on his podcast.

Topline
Rumble, a video platform that bills itself as “neutral” and “immune to cancel culture,” published a letter Tuesday to embattled podcast host Joe Rogan asking him to leave Spotify and distribute The Joe Rogan Experience through its service for $100 million, as it plans an ambitious public offering next quarter it hopes will value the company at $2 billion.
Musician Neil Young removed his music from the platform after asking Spotify to choose between him or Rogan.
Several videos promoted on the site’s homepage Monday were about Rogan and the fallout surrounding him.
Rumble has been sharing social media posts on Twitter about Rogan leaving Spotify for it since Friday.
